stem: The pediatric nurse is conducting an 18-month wellness visit and utilizing the M-CHAT-R/F (Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers). Based on the documentation in the M-CHAT Screening Log, match each observation with the correct developmental classification.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient: (Ryan, 18mo). Parent is concerned because Ryan 'doesn't play like his sister did.' 
Nurse's Observations: Ryan does not make eye contact when his name is called. He is currently lining up toy cars in a perfectly straight line and becomes extremely upset if the line is disturbed.

tabs.title: M-CHAT Screening Log
tabs.content:

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: Ryans's hearing was tested and is within normal limits. Growth (Height/Weight) is at the 50th percentile.

rows.text: Lining up toys in repetitive patterns rather than functional play
Lack of 'joint attention' (Not looking when someone points)
Regression or loss of previously learned language skills
Responding only to specific sounds but ignoring their name
Following a one-step command with a gesture

rationale.correct: Red flags (c1) for autism at 18 months include repetitive play (r1), lack of pointing/joint attention (r2), regression of language (r3), and lack of response to name (r4) especially when hearing is normal. Following a simple command (r5) is an expected developmental milestone (c2).
clinicalPearls: Autism screening (M-CHAT) is standard at the 18-month and 24-month visits.
The hallmark of ASD is a deficit in SOCIAL communication and the presence of repetitive behaviors.
Losing a skill (Regression) is ALWAYS a red flag in pediatrics.

questionTrap.trap: Believing that an autistic child will always have a low IQ.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that ASD is a 'spectrum'. Many children have normal or superior intelligence but still have severe social deficits.

mnemonic.title: SOCIAL
mnemonic.expansion: S-Social smile (missing). O-Only plays alone. C-Communication lag. I-Imaginative play (missing). A-Attention (Lack of). L-Lining up toys.
